Award.AwardTitle: Random Matrix Theory and High Dimensional Statistics
Award.AbstractNarration:
High dimensional data are becoming increasingly available from a wide
range of scientific investigations, including genomics, bioinformatics,
engineering, and climate studies. Sound analysis of such datasets poses
many statistical challenges. It calls for new statistical theory and methods
as well as new technical tools. In this collaborative research project, the
investigators will first develop results and technical tools in random matrix
theory and then take a unified approach using the technical tools developed
to study several important problems in high dimensional statistics
as well as applications in signal processing, physics, and mathematics.

The statistical and scientific objectives outlined in this proposal are interdisciplinary
and will establish connections among different fields - random matrix theory, high
dimensional statistics, signal processing, physics, and mathematics. The research
will also provide technical tools as well as methodology, to researchers in other
scientific fields who collect and analyze high dimensional data. These include,
but are not limited to, genomics, biostatistics, and electrical engineering. The procedures and algorithms developed in this project will be implemented and softwares developed will be made freely and publicly available on the web as open source
code along with the associated research reports so as to facilitate the dissemination of knowledge.

Institution.Name: University of Minnesota-Twin Cities
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

POR.DRECONTENT:
1. Publication. During this support, the PI has eight published/accepted papers,  and six papers were submitted, They were in the process of refereeing. The papers study problems on Random Matrices, Big Data and Random Geometry. In particular, the PI's paper with title "Distributions of Angles in Random Packing on Spheres" joined with Cai and Fan was cited by physicist Daniel Junghans. By using our results together with other tools, he studied "Weak Gravity Conjecture" from the Big Bang theory. The reference is Junghans, D. (2016). Large-field inflation with multiple axions and the weak gravity conjecture. Journal of High Energy Physics (2). 

 2. Seminars. With the support, the PI was able to run seminars weekly for the whole supported period. The seminars were hosted in University of Minnesota. In each meeting there were around eight participants, who are graduate students or post docs, professors of Statistics, Mathematics or Physics. The goal for the seminar is learning and discussing new topics related to the proposal. They include Random Partitions, Random Matrices, Machine Learning and the KPZ equation as a special kind of stochastic differential equations. The PI hosted and lectured most of the time.  

3. Conferences/seminar speakers. The PI presented fifteen lectures in the international conferences, and gave talks in another fifteen invited seminars both nationally and internationally. Through these activities, the PI's research results were communicated among many researchers, graduate students. At the same time, the PI collected valuable information and feedback to the supported project. The interactions among professors, students, professionals are part of the proposed plans.    

4. Training of visiting scholars. During the span of project, the PI hosted three visiting professors from China. The PI communicated more than once a week with each scholar on topics related to the project. Two of the visiting scholars collaborated with PI for two research papers. They were submitted for publication.  

 5. Training of students. The PI supervised three PhD students and one master students. Among them, one PhD and the master students completed their programs. The PI also traveled to China and presented a lecture to elementary school students in a rural area. The topics is "How to Learn Mathematics?"  

 

 

 


Last Modified: 02/25/2017
Modified by: Tiefeng Jiang
